clues.text: It took Russ Cook 352 days to run the length of this continent, from Cape Agulhas to the Mediterranean
In 2024 Anouk Garnier beat a record by rope climbing 361 feet to the second floor of this French landmark
In 2007 Alain Robert climbed an 88-story building with only his hands & feet while wearing this superhero costume, naturally
In 1955 Tex Johnston did this "roll"-ing aerial maneuver in a big Boeing plane & later wrote, "The airplane never knows it's inverted"
Jeanne Baret in the 1700s is credited with being the first woman to do this; she had to transfer ships to accomplish it
Tom Felton said Rupert Grint was fined 2,500 pounds (going to charity) over the 1st 2 films in this series for laughing mid-scene
You can see Matt LeBlanc try to hide real laughter as Joey ducks behind a panicked Ross, in search of a ring on this sitcom
On "SNL", Heidi Gardner could not take Mikey Day's makeup when he & Ryan Gosling played this animated MTV duo
After Tim Conway's ad-lib story about Siamese elephants, Vicki Lawrence broke this show's cast w/ "Sure that little (bleep) is through?"
Jack Nicholson, who may or may not have been under the influence, cracks up while talking about Venusians to Dennis Hopper in this film
Oxfam thinks Taylor Swift has too much money, as "every" one of these people "is a policy failure"
You're feeling wired, your heart is racing--you're this 15-letter word & probably should have skipped that third espresso
Hi, I'm shame. Do you know my cousin, this? He has a complex named after him, when one is awash with feelings of having done wrong
Hyperlipidemia, too much fat in the blood, is caused by an excess of this substance provided by your own liver plus pork & donuts
To us this Greek word means excess pride; to Aristotle, it meant shaming   others for one's own pleasure (perhaps out of pride)
He published both "The Eye Book" & "The Tooth Book" as Theo. LeSieg, the last name being an anagram of Geisel
Hawthorne's story "The Great Stone Face" refers to a natural landmark that was in the White Mountains of this state
He deciphered the power (& plot) of hero myths in his 1949 work "The Hero with a Thousand Faces"
Tea Cake is Janie Crawford's third husband in this classic by Zora Neale Hurston
Cultural appropriation is at the heart of this novel by R.F. Kuang; a white woman steals a manuscript written by her Asian friend
To confuse & thwart infiltrators, blind alleys with dead ends & zigzag patterns were used as part of constructing these
In 1915, British troops landed at Cape Helles near Gallipoli to try to seize this strait whose old name may be an easier get
British soldiers during the war were called Tommies & U.S. soldiers were called by this "flour"-y name
Allied troops from this Western Hemisphere country stormed Vimy Ridge in 1917; they took it at a cost of nearly 4,000 men
To halt a German advance during 1914's First Battle of the Marne, 600 of these transports brought 3,000 French troops to the front
Before these were tiny headphones, the term referred to little shoots of young corn
A 90-pack--that's 45 pairs!--of these from Bausch & Lomb should keep things clear for awhile
Before cellphones, every kid wanted a pair of these rhyming handheld communication devices
Galileo made a table of probabilities based on a set of 3 of these, but today we more often see them in pairs
Up to 7 feet long, the traditional Alaskan type of these are great for walking on deep, dry powder in open country
To wrench an ankle; ouch!
It's said to have finished off the nosy feline
Type of fund that invests in diversified securities
As a verb it can mean to sing joyously, perhaps at holiday time
This type of secret cult religion in the ancient Greco-Roman world offered unique experiences unlike those in the standard faiths

rounds.category: SCIENCE: MISSED IT BY THAT MUCH

clues.text: "How Deep Is" this, asks a song standard--a 2010 estimate says 12,080' mean depth so John Murray in 1888 was pretty close at 12,480'
In the 1860s John Newlands arranged the 56 known these according to a soon-discredited "Law of Octaves"
At this 7/16/1945 "Site", Fermi's guess on bomb yield was off by half--not bad for tossing paper in the air as the blast wave came
Hipparchus of Bithynia calculated this distance at a bit under 2 million miles; 93 million is more like it
clues.response: the distance from the Earth to the Sun

clues.text: The "Top 10 Erroneous Results" from Science News include a 2011 finding that these chargeless particles can outrace light
You'll want to use paper called kami that's thinner & often 6 inches square for this craft with a Japanese name
This word for heavy scissors used to cut metal or hair tells you what they do
Slate & marble are types of this rock, formed in most cases when its mineral composition changes
If you're baking, this alliterative paper will prevent your batter from sticking to the pan
With roots going back to 1649, this Finnish company began making its distinctive orange-handled scissors in 1967
Nabokov went off on this writer: "I read him... in the early '40s, something about bells... & bulls & I loathed it"
Charles Baudelaire gave this "Candide" author flowers--of evil!--when he called him "the king of nincompoops"
Norman Mailer bashed this man's fit, saying, "there is something silly about a man who wears a white suit all the time"
Oscar Wilde said there were 2 ways to dislike poetry, 1: just to dislike it. 2: to like this "Rape of the Lock" poet
W.H. Auden went in on this 19th century Brit, saying that "his wife"--also a poet--"probably didn't care for him very much"

LEWD BEER ID

BOB DRIED ALGAE

GLOBAL WEEKEND

rounds.text: Wadi al-Malekat in Arabic, this site near a similar & better known location was the burial place of Nefertari & others
